elements.content: From searching the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD), we noticed an exceptionally widespread distribution of the interatomic distances (from 2.39 to 3.52 Å) between thioether S atoms and Ag(I) ions, in comparison with the cases in other common ligands such as nitriles and pyridyls. The variable bonding distances point to a highly flexible and reversible nature of thioether−Ag(I) interaction, which might help crystallize large and complex organic molecules into ordered coordination networks under mild conditions. We provide a number of new structures for illustration. In 1, two Ag(I) ions are coordinated by three 1,2,3-tris(methylthio)phenyl groups (i.e., 9 S atoms) to form a three-bladed paddlewheel block as a node for an enlarged honeycomb sheet. In 2, a porphyrin molecule with four 1,2,3-tris(phenylthio)phenyl groups coordinates to Ag(I) atoms to form a parallelogram net, featuring free-standing phenylthio groups in the channel. In 3, a starburst molecule with six 4-methylthiophenyl groups attached to the triphenylene core is crystallized with AgOTf (triflate) to form a complex three-dimensional net, with a supramolecular topology featuring a combination of edge-sharing octahedra (the rutile chain) and vertex-sharing octahedra (the ReO3 chain).

elements.content: We study highly multidentate, large molecules as building units for coordination networks. For example, a starburst molecule with six 4-methylthiophenyl groups attached to the triphenylene core is crystallized with AgOTf (triflate) to form a complex three-dimensional net, with a supramolecular topology featuring a combination of edge-sharing octahedra (the rutile chain) and vertex-sharing octahedra (the ReO3 chain).

elements.content: The incorporation of ever more sophisticated organic functionality is of both fundamental and practical importance in the field of coordination networks, as one major advantage of these networks hinges upon the much richer chemical functionalities in comparison to the inorganic crystalline materials. In this connection, large and complex organic molecules present particular interest as building blocks. On the one hand, the sheer size of the constituent molecules evokes an aesthetic appeal that constantly propels synthetic chemists to push up the structural scale in both discrete and extended structures. On the other hand, large organic ligands generally offer richer functional diversity for advanced materials properties in the prospective solids. For example, large organic aromatic π electron systems generally give rise to intense fluorescence for potential solid-state sensing purposes, and tend to form intermolecular stacks that are of interest for molecular electronics studies.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The incorporation of ever more sophisticated organic functionality is of both fundamental and practical importance in the field of coordination networks, as one major advantage of these networks hinges upon the much richer chemical functionalities in comparison to the inorganic crystalline materials. In this connection, large and complex organic molecules present particular interest as building blocks. On the one hand, the sheer size of the constituent molecules evokes an aesthetic appeal that constantly propels synthetic chemists to push up the structural scale in both discrete and extended structures. On the other hand, large organic ligands generally offer richer functional diversity for advanced materials properties in the prospective solids. For example, large organic aromatic π electron systems generally give rise to intense fluorescence for potential solid-state sensing purposes, and tend to form intermolecular stacks that are of interest for molecular electronics studies.

elements.content: In designing large-size molecules for coordination networks, we are interested in systems that are amenable to crystallization with inorganic linkers under mild conditions. In this connection, we have taken note of a number of advantages provided by thioethers as the building blocks for coordination networks. (1) The organic groups (e.g., the methyl or phenyl groups in L1, L2, and L3 in Scheme ) can be modified to take on new functionality, and to control the volume of the ligand and interpenetration of the network. (2) The thioether S atom contains two lone pairs of electrons, and therefore can accommodate the metal ion in a relatively open space and adaptable orientations; by comparison, -CN and pyridinyl groups have only one lone pair, and are more constricted in their bonding directions. The large number of reported thioether-based coordination networks testifies to the usefulness of thioethers as building units.

In this paper, we highlight yet another salient advantage of the thioether ligands that is likely to facilitate the crystallization of coordination networks under mild conditions. This is about the exceptional bonding flexibility that is reflected in the largely variable bonding distances between the thioether S atom and soft metal ions such as Ag(I). We will demonstrate this phenomenon from the extensive data uncovered from the CSD database, and supply three new structures to further illustrate use of this flexible interaction for crystallizing large-size organic molecules into coordination networks.

elements.content: Starting materials, reagents, and solvents were purchased from commercial sources (Aldrich and Fisher Scientific) and used without further purification unless stated otherwise. Solution 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a 300 MHz (or 200 MHz) Varian YH300 superconducting-magnet high-field NMR spectrometer at room temperature, with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of crystal samples (packed inside a sealed capillary) were collected on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a Göbel mirror that produced parallel X-ray radiation (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5406 Å). The power of the sealed X-ray tube was 40 kV and 40 mA. Elemental analysis was performed by a Vario EL III CHNOS elemental analyzer. Luminescent spectra (i.e., as in ) were measured using a Horiba Jobin Yvon FL-1057 spectrofluorometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on Seiko Instruments SSC/5200 under flowing He gas (20 mLmin−1) and the heating rate was 5 °C/min. Additional synthetic steps for L1, L2, and L3 are in the .

elements.content: Single crystal XRD analyses (data collection, structure solution, and refinement) were conducted on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX CCD system using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at 100(2) K. All absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS program. The structures were solved and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F o 2 using SHELXL 6.14 (Bruker AXS Inc., Madison, Wisconsin, USA, 2003). Highly disordered and ill-defined solvent and anion moieties were commonly encountered in these large-size open-framework structures, and the program SQUEEZE and heavy restraints were applied for proper rendering of these fragments. Selected crystallographic data are summarized in Table . Detailed treatment of the diffuse moieties and other aspects of the refinements are included in the following crystallographic data files as part of the . CCDC-683358 (1), CCDC-683207 (2), and CCDC-683357 (3) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/datarequest/cif.

A Schlenk tube (100 mL) was loaded with a magnetic stirring bar, bis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(II) chloride (70.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), triphenylphosphine (120.0 mg, 0.46 mmol), copper(I) iodide (35.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), 4-ethynyl-3,4,5-tris(methylthio)benzene (0.50 g, 2.08 mmol), and tris(4-iodophenyl)amine (0.39 g, 0.63 mmol). The Schlenk tube was then connected to a vacuum manifold, evacuated, and back-filled with nitrogen gas. After the Schlenk was thus purged three times, a 2:1 triethylamine/tetrahydrofuran (THF) mixture (30.0 mL, prepurged with nitrogen gas) was injected via cannula under nitrogen protection. The Schlenk tube was then sealed with the plug and stirred at 100 °C overnight. After being cooled down to rt, the reaction mixture was worked up by the same procedure as that used for 1-trimethylsilylethynyl-3,4,5-tris(methylthio)benzene (see ). The crude product was then purified by flash chromatography (silica gel, flash column separation with 1:1 hexane/dichloromethane as the eluent) to provide a light yellow solid (0.30 g, 50% based on tris(4-iodophenyl)amine). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 2.36 (s, 9H), 2.46 (s, 18H), 6.97 (s, 6H), 7.10 (d, 6H), 7.47 (d, 6H) ppm. 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 18.90, 20.86, 89.23, 91.10, 117.90, 122.16, 124.50, 125.31, 128.47, 133.49, 147.30, 147.45 ppm.

elements.content: A nitrobenzene (NB) solution (2.0 mL) of L1 (9.6 mg, 0.01 mmol) was added to an NB solution (2.0 mL) of AgBF4 (3.9 mg, 0.02 mmol) in a vial and the mixture was filtered to give a light yellow solution. The filtrate (held in a loosely capped vial) was then placed into a larger vial containing about 10 mL of hexane, with care taken to prevent direct contact of the filtrate and the hexane. The larger vial was then sealed tight and placed in a dark, quiet place for the vapor transport experiment. White needle-like single crystals (10.0 mg, 74% yield based on L1) suitable for X-ray data set collection were formed over a period of about 7 days. To help determine the chemical composition of the as-synthesized crystals, freshly made crystals of 1 (3.0 mg) were dissolved in a mixture of DMSO-d 6 (0.5 mL) and CDCl3 (0.5 mL) for 1H NMR measurement. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6, CDCl3): δ 7.03 (s, 12H), 7.10 (d, 12H), 7.56 (d, 12H), 7.68 (t, 6H), 7.85 (t, 3H) and 8.23 (d, 6H) ppm. The NMR spectra of 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6 , CDCl3) for nitrobenzene: δ 7.58 (t, 2H), 7.74 (t, 1H), 8.20 (d, 2H) ppm. Combined with the above NMR data of pure L1, the L1/NB ratio is thus established as 1:1.25 (i.e., L1·2AgBF4·1.25C6H5NO2). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for L1·2AgBF4·1.25C6H5NO2: C 46.7, H 3.44, N 2.10; found: C 45.16, H 3.61, N 2.04. This composition is also supported by the TGA measurement (see ).

elements.content: To an oxygen-free solution of 3,4,5-tris(phenylthio)benzaldehyde (0.43 g, 1.0 mmol) in dichloromethane (anhydrous, 50.0 mL) was added pyrrole (68.0 mg, 99.0%, 1.0 mmol, prepurged with nitrogen for 5 min) under nitrogen protection. After 5 min, boron trifluoride diethyl etherate (0.1 mL, 1 M in dichloromethane) was injected, while the mixture was stirred using a magnetic stirring bar. The mixture was then covered with the aluminum foil and the stirring was continued for another 2 h, followed by addition of p-chloranil (2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzoquinone, 0.20 g, 99.0%, 0.82 mmol) into the resultant dark red-brown solution. The burgundy mixture was then heated to reflux for 1 h. After the mixture was cooled to rt, the mixture was transferred into a round-bottom flask and silica gel was added. The solvent was removed in vacuo, and the purple residue was loaded on the top of a prepacked silica gel column. The column was eluted first with 50% (by volume) dichloromethane in hexane to remove the side products, and then with 70% dichloromethane in hexane to get the sample. After evaporation of the solvent in vacuo, the pure product was obtained as a shiny purple solid (0.29 g, mp 335−337 °C w/ decomposition, 60% yield based on 3,4,5-tris(phenylthio)benzaldehyde). 1H NMR (200 MHz, DMF-d 6): δ 7.06−7.30 (m, 24H), 7.36 (s, 8H), 7.56−7.73 (m, 36H), 8.85 (s, 8H) ppm. Solution 13C NMR could not be obtained from our instruments due to the low solubility in common deuterated solvents. Further characterization could be found in the single crystal X-ray diffraction study of the extended networks based on Zn-T3PhTPP and silver triflate.

elements.content: This was obtained in 99.0% yield as a red purple solid by refluxing a mixture of 2H-T3PhTPP (0.12 g, 0.063 mmol) and zinc acetate dihydrate (0.14 g, 99%, 0.63 mmol) in chloroform (dry, 30.0 mL) for 1 h followed by filtration through a silica gel plug. elements.content: A nitrobenzene solution of Zn-T3PhTPP (0.50 mL, 1.4 mM) and a nitrobenzene solution of silver triflate (AgOTf, 0.5 mL, 11.2 mM) were mixed in a vial. After adding N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) (0.1 mL) to dissolve the precipitate, the solution was filtered through a syringe frit into another vial. The vial with the filtrate was then placed into a bigger vial containing a reservoir of benzene (∼10 mL). The bigger vial was tightly capped and placed in the dark for the vapor transport experiment. After 10 days, purple-red, block-like crystals (1.7 mg, 41% yield based on L2) suitable for X-ray data set collection were obtained. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for L2·2AgOTf·DMA·2C6H6·C6H5NO2: C 58.87, H 3.60, N 2.94; found: C 57.91, H 3.52, N 2.84. This composition is also supported by the TGA measurement (see   ).

elements.content: To a Schlenk tube containing a mixture of 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexabromotriphenylene (0.702 g, 1.0 mmol) and tetrakis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(0) (0.30 g, 0.26 mmol) in toluene (25.0 mL) were added a suspension of 4-methylthiophenylboronic acid (1.68 g, 10.0 mmol) in ethanol (8.0 mL) and an aqueous solution of potassium carbonate (5.0 mL, 2.0 M) under nitrogen protection. The mixture was heated under reflux at 120 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature and poured into dichloromethane. The organic layer was washed with water, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified on silica gel using a mixture of dichloromethane and hexane (the CH2Cl2/hexane ratio was varied gradually from 1:2 to 1:1) to yield a white solid (0.52 g, 54% yield based on 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexabromotriphenylene). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 2.51 (s, 18H), 7.22 (m, 24H), 8.63 (s, 6H) ppm. 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 15.89, 125.76, 126.35, 129.13, 130.65, 137.49, 138.26, 139.53 ppm.

The mixture was heated under reflux at 120 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature and poured into dichloromethane. The organic layer was washed with water, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified on silica gel using a mixture of dichloromethane and hexane (the CH2Cl2/hexane ratio was varied gradually from 1:2 to 1:1) to yield a white solid (0.52 g, 54% yield based on 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexabromotriphenylene). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 2.51 (s, 18H), 7.22 (m, 24H), 8.63 (s, 6H) ppm. 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 15.89, 125.76, 126.35, 129.13, 130.65, 137.49, 138.26, 139.53 ppm.

elements.content: A nitrobenzene (NB) solution (2.0 mL) of L3 (19.2 mg, 0.02 mmol) was added to an NB solution (4.0 mL) of AgOTf (25.7 mg, 0.1 mmol) in a vial and the mixture was filtered to give a light yellow solution. The filtrate (held in a loosely capped vial) was then placed into a larger vial containing about 20 mL of hexane, with care taken to prevent direct contact of the filtrate and the hexane. The larger vial was then sealed tight and placed in a dark, quiet place for the vapor transport experiment. White needle-like single crystals (21.0 mg, 58.5% yield based on L3) suitable for X-ray data set collection were formed over a period of about 7 days. X-ray powder diffraction of the product indicated a single phase consistent with the single crystal structure (see   ). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 2L3·5AgOTf·2H2O·1.5C6H5NO2: C 48.74, H 3.24, N 0.64; found: C 48.33, H 3.33, N 0.62. This composition is also supported by TGA measurements (see   ).

elements.content: We present our survey of the Cambridge Structural Database (ConQuest version 1.8) to illustrate the bonding flexibility between thioether sulfur atoms and metal centers. For this, we searched for the interatomic distances of six types of coordination interactions commonly used for constructing coordination networks. These are the pyridyl nitrogen and Cu+ (pyrCu), pyridyl nitrogen and Ag+ (pyrAg), nitrile N and Cu+ (RCNCu), nitrile N and Ag+ (RCNAg), thioether S and Cu+ (R2SCu), and thioether S and Ag+ (R2SAg). To arrive at a simple and meaningful comparison, we have chosen the chemically similar congeners of Ag(I) and Cu(I) ions, and we wish to compare their bonding behaviors toward the neutral donors of pyridyls, nitriles, and thioethers. For example, we do not extend the comparison to the ionic carboxylate species which are also widely used for forming crystalline nets (i.e., MOFs). In our understanding, it is the strong ionic character that largely accounts for their outstanding versatility in forming crystalline nets with labile metal ions such as Zn2+ and Cu2+: the ionic nature provides for effective solvation of the ions in polar solvents, and thus promotes the reversibility of the carboxylate−metal bond formation (especially under hydrothermal conditions). To be sure, the nitrile and pyridyl groups are by themselves very versatile donors for forming crystalline nets; what we wish to emphasize here is 2-fold: (1) the bonding flexibility of thioethers is exceptional even in comparison to these versatile ligands; (2) with the ease of molecular synthesis and functionalization, thioethers offer additional advantages for growing complex coordination nets. Let us now move on with the CSD search.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussions

Literature Search

We present our survey of the Cambridge Structural Database (ConQuest version 1.8) to illustrate the bonding flexibility between thioether sulfur atoms and metal centers. For this, we searched for the interatomic distances of six types of coordination interactions commonly used for constructing coordination networks. These are the pyridyl nitrogen and Cu+ (pyrCu), pyridyl nitrogen and Ag+ (pyrAg), nitrile N and Cu+ (RCNCu), nitrile N and Ag+ (RCNAg), thioether S and Cu+ (R2SCu), and thioether S and Ag+ (R2SAg). To arrive at a simple and meaningful comparison, we have chosen the chemically similar congeners of Ag(I) and Cu(I) ions, and we wish to compare their bonding behaviors toward the neutral donors of pyridyls, nitriles, and thioethers. For example, we do not extend the comparison to the ionic carboxylate species which are also widely used for forming crystalline nets (i.e., MOFs). In our understanding, it is the strong ionic character that largely accounts for their outstanding versatility in forming crystalline nets with labile metal ions such as Zn2+ and Cu2+: the ionic nature provides for effective solvation of the ions in polar solvents, and thus promotes the reversibility of the carboxylate-metal bond formation (especially under hydrothermal conditions). To be sure, the nitrile and pyridyl groups are by themselves very versatile donors for forming crystalline nets; what we wish to emphasize here is 2-fold: (1) the bonding flexibility of thioethers is exceptional even in comparison to these versatile ligands; (2) with the ease of molecular synthesis and functionalization, thioethers offer additional advantages for growing complex coordination nets. Let us now move on with the CSD search.

elements.content: For completeness, in each search, we included all the intramolecular and intermolecular contacts, and we also set the distance range from the regular covalent bond distance to the sum of the corresponding van der Waals distances (e.g., for the R2SAg case, the range is from 1.50 to 3.52 Å, vdW radii provided by the Database). For each type of the interactions, a large number of hits for the distances were uncovered: pyrCu, 6240 hits (distances distributed between 1.80 and 3.40 Å); pyrAg, 2591 (between 2.00 and 3.50 Å); R2SCu, 697 (between 2.10 and 3.40 Å); R2SAg, 1423 (between 2.39 and 3.52 Å).

For each type of the interactions, a large number of hits for the distances were uncovered: pyrCu, 6240 hits (distances distributed between 1.80 and 3.40 Å); pyrAg, 2591 (between 2.00 and 3.50 Å); R2SCu, 697 (between 2.10 and 3.40 Å); R2SAg, 1423 (between 2.39 and 3.52 Å).

elements.content: To study the variability of the interatomic distances within each type of interaction, we assign a percentile rank to each distance. For example, the distance 2.300 Å is longer than 1380 of the total 2591 distances, and therefore a percentile rank of 1380/2591 = 0.5326 is assigned to it; the distance 2.300 Å occurs nine times among all the 2591 hits, and nine consecutive percentile ranks are allotted to the distance 2.300 Å, with an increment of 1/2591 between the neighboring ranks. To help visualize the distribution of the distances, we then plot the percentile ranks against the distances, as is shown in Figure . The shape of the resultant graphs exposes the variability of the interatomic distances in an intuitive manner. For example, the steep ascent of the graph for pyrCu from 2.0 to 2.1 Å indicates that the majority (over 70%) of the N···Cu distances are confined within this narrow range; the variability of the distance is small. By comparison, the graph for R2SAg (thioether-Ag+) features the slowest slope in Figure , indicating exceptionally variable bonding strength in this type of interactions. Specifically, 60% of the distances occur between 2.45 and 2.80 Å, and the remaining 40% are quite evenly spread from 2.80 Å up to the vdW distances. Along the same line, one can qualitatively observe from Figure that the plot for RCN···Ag also features significant variability of the interatomic distances (although not quite so as the R2S···Ag plot).

elements.content: Distribution of pyridyl N···Ag+, N···Cu+, nitrile N···Ag+, N···Cu+, and thioether S···Ag+, S···Cu+ distances in CSD database. A distance of 2.6 Å on R2S···Ag+ registers a rank of 0.4, meaning 2.6 Å is longer than 40% of all the thioether S···Ag+ contacts retrieved. The steep step of the C5H5N···Cu+ curve thus indicates a large majority of the contacts occur around 2.0 Å, while the slower slope of R2S···Ag+ indicates a wider distribution of the distances (the sampling size is big, with over 800 data points retrieved for each type of contact).

elements.content: In general, the variability of interatomic distances of Ag(I) ions appears to be greater than that of Cu(I) ions, which might arise partly from the more diffuse electron clouds of the Ag atoms (i.e., Ag is a softer element than Cu); the bonding energy thus becomes less sensitive to the variation of the interatomic distance. On the ligand side, the distance variability increases in the order of pyridyls, nitriles, and thioethers, which reflects the generally stronger coordinating ability of the pyridyls (e.g., relative to the nitriles), and the thioether S atoms being generally a softer Lewis base than the nitrogen atoms in coordination chemistry. The flexible thioether S−Ag(I) interaction is also reminiscent of the secondary interactions widely observed in the solid-state chemistry of Pb(II), Bi(III), Te(IV), I(III) and other related species, even though the electronic nature of the bonding interaction here might differ greatly from the d10 Ag(I) ion. It is beyond the scope of this work to delve into the electronic nature of these secondary interactions; the objective here is rather to utilize the observed flexibility of thioether−Ag(I) interactions, and to achieve larger size and richer functionality in the organic building blocks of coordination networks. For this, the readily available, air-stable, and soluble silver salts (e.g., AgOTf and AgBF4) as the source of discrete, unipositive Ag(I) ions offer additional experimental convenience.

On the ligand side, the distance variability increases in the order of pyridyls, nitriles, and thioethers, which reflects the generally stronger coordinating ability of the pyridyls (e.g., relative to the nitriles), and the thioether S atoms being generally a softer Lewis base than the nitrogen atoms in coordination chemistry. The flexible thioether S-Ag(I) interaction is also reminiscent of the secondary interactions widely observed in the solid-state chemistry of Pb(II), Bi(III), Te(IV), I(III) and other related species, even though the electronic nature of the bonding interaction here might differ greatly from the d10 Ag(I) ion. It is beyond the scope of this work to delve into the electronic nature of these secondary interactions; the objective here is rather to utilize the observed flexibility of thioether-Ag(I) interactions, and to achieve larger size and richer functionality in the organic building blocks of coordination networks. For this, the readily available, air-stable, and soluble silver salts (e.g., AgOTf and AgBF4) as the source of discrete, unipositive Ag(I) ions offer additional experimental convenience.

elements.content: The exceptional bonding flexibility of thioethers (and to a lesser degree nitriles) indicate that thioether groups could act either as a binding site that provides for regular coordination bonding and secondary interactions, or as free-standing groups without apparent association with the metal centers. Such bonding flexibility points to additional reversibility of the thioether−Ag(I) interaction, and may help the assembly of organic molecules into well-ordered, crystalline coordination networks. However, it is not our intention to label thioethers as a “cure-all” for crystallizing coordination networks. After all, crystallization is a highly dynamic and complex process, and the ease of obtaining a crystalline network depends on the experimental conditions as well as other structural features of the organic molecules, including symmetry, conformational rigidity, and the overall functionality. The overall intent here is instead to probe the network formation behaviors of ever larger organic molecules. In this connection, the synthetic availability and structural modifiability of the thioether molecules provide unique advantages in ligand design and synthesis, whereas the flexible interactions with metal ions (e.g., Ag+) may facilitate the crystallization process on the practical level.

elements.content: The following recounts studies on molecules L1, L2, and L3 (Scheme ) as an effort along this direction. In designing these molecules, we have incorporated several considerations. First, the molecules are designed to be highly symmetrical, both for aesthetic reasons and for facilitating the formation of crystalline products. Second, the molecules contain electronically interesting large aromatic π-electron systems, for L1, the triphenylamine core; for L2 the metalloporphyrin core; for L3, the hexaphenyltriphenylene core. Third, we experiment with novel, complex multidenticity of these thioether-based ligands, in order to uncover interesting structural features (e.g., local coordination bonding patterns and network connectivity) in the prospective networks. Specifically, L1 and L2 feature the 1,2,3-tris(organylthio) unit as a relatively unexplored trident-like chelating motif for growing coordination networks, while L3 features a starburst planar hexapod geometry, which is also rarely used in the molecular building blocks of coordination nets.

elements.content: The trigonal molecule L1 crystallizes with AgBF4 to form a boron nitride (BN)-type honeycomb net (1), in which the two types of 3-connected nodes can be respectively taken as the center of the molecule L1 and the center of a chelation aggregate of the thioether groups and the Ag(I) ions (see Figures and ). The chelation node is based on the interaction of two Ag(I) ions and the three tris(methylthio)phenyl groups from the adjoining L1 molecules, and the local coordination motif is shown in Figure .

elements.content: The overall coordination motif resembles a three-bladed paddlewheel, in which the two Ag atoms lie on the shaft and the three tris(methylthio)phenyl groups form the blades. In approaching the Ag1−Ag2 shaft, the sulfur atoms are differentiated into three groups according to their relative positions to the two Ag atoms (see Figure a): the top three (S1, S4, S7), bottom three (S3, S6, S9), and the middle three (S2, S5, S8). The top ones are closest to Ag2 and bond to it in a roughly trigonal planar fashion, and the bottom ones are similarly bonded to Ag1. The six Ag−S interactions thus formed are quite short (2.59−2.64 Å). The middle three sulfur atoms, by comparison, are disposed to access both Ag1 and Ag2. The two Ag−S contacts from each S atom are quite disparate in lengths: 2.78 and 3.35 Å for S2; 2.85 and 3.24 Å for S5; 2.98 and 3.30 Å for S8. The Ag−S distances around the Ag1 ion divide into two distinct groups: the four short ones of 2.59, 2.62, 2.64, and 2.78 Å, and the two longer ones of 3.24 and 3.30 Å. By comparison, the six Ag−S distances around the Ag2 atom spread out more evenly, with the intermediate values of 2.85 and 2.98 Å, which bridge the shorter ones (2.60, 2.62, 2.63 Å), and the long one of 3.35 Å. Along the shaft, the Ag1 and Ag2 ions are each associated with a BF4 − ion (at Ag−F distances of 2.65 and 2.84 Å, respectively). The BF4 − ion on Ag1 is, however, refined with an occupancy factor of 0.616 (the other set of BF4 − sites, at 0.384 occupancy, is farther away, and nonbonding to Ag1), suggesting that only about 61% of the Ag1 sites are associated with the BF4 − ion.

elements.content: The packing of the honeycomb sheets can be dissected into dimeric aggregates, in which the two nets related by a center of symmetry are aligned in a staggered fashion so that the molecular centers fall almost vertically from one net to the other, while the Ag−S coordination units overlap with and extend into the hexagonal voids of the other net (see Figure , the spacing between the two nets being about 5.23 Å). Such dimers are then stacked in a slightly slipped fashion in an ABAB··· mode along the c axis to complete the 3D structure. Oval-shaped channels are formed along the c axis, and they probably contain the nitrobenzene guests, which are not located by the X-ray diffraction studies, but are shown to exist by solution H1 NMR, elemental analysis, and TGA measurements (see and ), and give a composition of L1·2AgBF4·1.25C6H5NO2 for the as-made sample of 1. Calculation using the Platon software indicates about 47% of the unit cell volume is potentially solvent accessible. Removing the nitrobenzene guests by evacuating on the as-made crystalline samples, however, led to a nondiffracting powder, indicating the collapse of the host framework.

elements.content: To summarize this structure: (1) the wide-ranging Ag−S distances (from 2.59 to 3.4 Å) observed here are consistent with the general pattern uncovered from the literature (Figure ), and they generate within a single structure rich bonding features resulting from the flexible Ag(I)−thioether interaction. (2) The bonding flexibility is also reflected in the integration of the complex Ag(I)−thioether aggregate as an interconnected node within this crystalline network. As the formation of the nodes constitutes the essential steps for building the network, reversible Ag(I)−thioether interaction is crucial for assembling the complex nodes in a growing lattice.

elements.content: The porphyrin-based molecule L2 and AgOTf (OTf: triflate) crystallize in the presence of DMA (N,N-dimethylacetamide), benzene, and nitrobenzene to form compound 2, which features a network with the composition of L2·2AgOTf, as well as the guests of DMA, C6H6, and C6H5NO2. Although an overall composition of L2·2AgOTf·DMA·2C6H6·C6H5NO2 can be derived from elemental and thermalgravimetric analyses, the precise location of the guest molecules from the X-ray diffraction data is difficult because of their disordered and ill-defined positions (see the cif file in for more information). The refined crystal structure (in the acentric space group Cc), however, reveals unequivocally the coordination motifs around the Ag centers and the overall network structure. As shown in Figures and , the coordination between the Ag(I) ion and the phenylthio groups of molecules of L2 resulted in a parallelogram net, in which the molecular centers of L2 topologically serve as the 4-connected nodes, and the Ag(I) ions as linear connections.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of 2: Bonding and Nonbonding Thioether Groups--Flexibility in Full Display

The porphyrin-based molecule L2 and AgOTf (OTf: triflate) crystallize in the presence of DMA (N,N-dimethylacetamide), benzene, and nitrobenzene to form compound 2, which features a network with the composition of L2⋅2AgOTf, as well as the guests of DMA, C6H6, and C6H5NO2. Although an overall composition of L2⋅2AgOTf⋅DMA⋅2C6H6⋅C6H5NO2 can be derived from elemental and thermalgravimetric analyses, the precise location of the guest molecules from the X-ray diffraction data is difficult because of their disordered and ill-defined positions (see the cif file in  for more information). The refined crystal structure (in the acentric space group Cc), however, reveals unequivocally the coordination motifs around the Ag centers and the overall network structure. As shown in Figures  and , the coordination between the Ag(I) ion and the phenylthio groups of molecules of L2 resulted in a parallelogram net, in which the molecular centers of L2 topologically serve as the 4-connected nodes, and the Ag(I) ions as linear connections.

elements.content: Compared with the previous structure of 1, the crystal structure of 2 displays even larger variability in its Ag−S distances, ranging from regular coordination bonds (e.g., 2.51 Å), to a secondary contact of 3.37 Å, and to completely nonbonding distances (i.e., the S atoms being free-standing). The local bonding features for the two crystallographically inequivalent Ag+ ions are shown in Figure . The Ag1 atom is bound by two tris(phenylthio)phenyl groups (one from each of the two adjacent ligands). Specifically, it is chelated by two pairs of the phenylthio groups in a square pyramidal geometry, with the S atoms at the basal corners, and the Ag(I) ion at the apex. Among the four Ag(I)−S bonds three (bond lengths: 2.600, 2.627, and 2.677 Å) are notably shorter than the fourth one (bond length: 2.867 Å), while the remaining two phenylthio groups (S1 and S9 in Figure a) are not associated with the Ag ions. Besides the S atoms, a triflate anion approaches the Ag(I) ion along the vertical height of the square pyramid, and forms an Ag−O bond with a distance of 2.412 Å.

elements.content: The Ag2 atom is also associated with two tris(phenylthio)phenyl groups from the neighboring molecules of L2 (Figure b). The overall coordination motif is similar to that of Ag1, with four S atoms at the base of a square pyramid, and the other two S atoms being free-standing. However, the variation of the Ag2−S distances is larger, with three short ones (2.511, 2.555, 2.648 Å), and a significantly longer one (3.366 Å) that can be categorized as a weak secondary interaction. The associated triflate anion is also disposed along the height of the square pyramid, but appears to be bonded a little more strongly than that of Ag1, with an Ag−O distance of 2.411 Å and an additional Ag−O contact of 3.172 Å. Substantial voids exist in the overall crystal structure, and they contain the OTf − anions and the solvent molecules (benzene and nitrobenzene). Similar to compound 1, the crystalline order of the network of 2 was lost upon evacuation of the guest molecules. The presence of the free-standing thioether groups in this network, however, inspires us to aim for a more robust porous system decorated with free-standing thioether units, in order to achieve richer adsorption phenomena and guest−host chemistry in the solid state (e.g., for the uptake of metal salt via the free-standing thioether groups).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 3 (space group: P1̅; composition: 2L3·5AgOTf·2H2O·1.5C6H5NO2) features a 3D network based on multifarious coordination interactions between the Ag(I) ions and the star-shaped hexapod ligand of L3. To decipher the network connectivity, we first treat as a building unit the two centrosymmetrically related L3 molecules that are aggregated through π−π stacking of the triphenylene cores (see Figure , interplanar distance: 3.376 Å). How do the 12 sulfur atoms in this L3 dimeric unit, an exceptionally multidentate unit, interact with the silver ions to form the network?
elements.clean_text:
Structure of 3: Starburst Hexapod and a Supramolecular 3D Topology

The crystal structure of 3 (space group: P1̅; composition: 2L3⋅5AgOTf⋅2H2O⋅1.5C6H5NO2) features a 3D network based on multifarious coordination interactions between the Ag(I) ions and the star-shaped hexapod ligand of L3. To decipher the network connectivity, we first treat as a building unit the two centrosymmetrically related L3 molecules that are aggregated through π-π stacking of the triphenylene cores (see Figure , interplanar distance: 3.376 Å). How do the 12 sulfur atoms in this L3 dimeric unit, an exceptionally multidentate unit, interact with the silver ions to form the network?

elements.content: Two L3 molecules aggregated through the π−π stacking of the triphenylene cores in the crystal structure of 3. S atoms: yellow spheres; C atoms: gray sticks.
elements.clean_text: 6  Two L3 molecules aggregated through the π-π stacking of the triphenylene cores in the crystal structure of 3. S atoms: yellow spheres; C atoms: gray sticks.

elements.content: The crystal structure contains three types of crystallographically independent Ag+ ions, and they provide two types of links across the L3 dimeric units. As shown in Figure , the first type of interlink can be considered as topologically 4-connected, and it is based on two Ag2 sites and an Ag3 site that serve to conjoin four dimeric units of L3. A total of six sulfur atoms are involved in this interlink. Among these, S3 and S6 belong to the same L3 dimer, while S4 belongs to a second L3 dimer. The remaining S atoms (S3′, S4′′, and S6′) are related by a center of symmetry to the above three S atoms. That is to say, for each L3 dimer, two types of coordination links are thus formed with the four surrounding Ag2−Ag3 units, one type involving two S atoms (e.g., S3 and S6) and the other type involving one S atom (e.g., S4); thus two different types of rods are used to illustrate the resultant net thus formed between the L3 dimers and the Ag2−Ag3 units (see Figure b). Overall, each L3 dimer is linked with four of the 4-connected Ag2−Ag3 building units, resulting in a complex 2D structure topologically equivalent to a parallelogram net along the (010) plane. A total of six sulfur atoms form each L3 dimer are engaged in the linkage with the four surrounding Ag2−Ag3 units.

elements.content: The remaining six sulfur atoms on the L3 dimer interact with the Ag1 atoms to furnish links across the above 2D layers to complete the 3D structure (Figure ). Each interlayer link involves two Ag1 atoms, in which the Ag1 atom is bound by three S atoms. To clearly describe the interlayer link, let us suppose the two linked L3 dimers are D1 and D2, and the two constituent Ag1 atoms are Ag1 and Ag1′. Thus, Ag1 picks up one S atom (e.g., S1 in Figure a) from D1 and two S atoms from D2 (e.g., S2 and S5 in Figure a), while Ag1′ picks up two S atoms from D1 and one S atom from D2. Each individual link as such engages three sulfur atoms from each of the two associated L3 dimers: the two Ag1 atoms are confined between the two L3 dimers and topologically constitute a single rod across the two L3 dimers. Overall, each L3 dimer is equipped with two such links (Figure b), and together with the four links with the above Ag2−Ag3 units, acts as a six-connected node.

elements.content: The entire network can thus be simplified as a 4,6-connected 3D net, consisting of 4-connected 2D nets that are interlinked through half of the nodes (i.e., the 6-connected nodes, see Figure a). Notice that the 6-connected and the 4-connected nodes here alternate with one another within the constituent 2D net. This simple 3D topology is mostly known among a group of cyanometalate hybrid coordination networks. There is, however, one subtle difference: here in 3, the 6-connected node is associated with three types of chemically distinct connections, whereas in the cyanometalate systems each 6-connected node has only two types of connections. In the language of structural inorganic chemistry, this structure type can be described as being based on vertex- and edge-sharing octahedra (Figure b): the octahedra first share the four coplanar edges to form the 2d layers, which then merge into the full 3D structure by sharing the remaining two vertices. The rows of edge-sharing octahedra is reminiscent of the so-called rutile (TiO2) chains, while the linear array of vertex-sharing octahedra parallels the prototypical ReO3 chains based on the ReO6 units.

elements.content: We now mention some other structural features of 3. Atom Ag1 has a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry from three thioether S atoms and one oxygen atom from a water molecule included in the crystallization process (Ag−O distance: 2.406 Å); Ag2 features a similar coordination environment but with the water replaced by a triflate anion (Ag−O distance: 2.465 Å). Atom Ag3 is evenly disordered over two sites (1.34 Å apart) at the core of the centrosymmetric Ag2−Ag3 block (see Figure ), and the coordination geometry is quite different. The two sites of Ag3 are surrounded by four coplanar S atoms, and two triflate anions at the axial positions (both anion sites are ordered and fully occupied). Focusing on each single site of Ag3, one sees a distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry with three equatorial thioether S atoms and two axial triflate O atoms (Ag−O distances: 2.478 and 2.729 Å). A tally of the Ag/triflate ratio so far indicates that 1/5 of the triflate ions are not located by this diffraction data set; apparently they exist in the interstices of the structure, and are not coordinated to the network. Overall, a chemical formula of 2L3·5AgOTf·2H2O·1.5C6H5NO2 was derived from elemental and thermogravimetric analyses. The solvent-accessible domains account for about 34% of the unit cell volume (calculated with the PLATON program), and exist as channels interconnected in all three directions along the a, b, and c axes. Also located in the channels are nitrobenzene guests, which are concentrated in the channels along the b direction. However, X-ray powder diffraction studies indicate that the crystallinity of the solid state sample quickly (e.g., over two or three hours) degrades upon separation from the mother liquor and exposure in air.

elements.content: One common feature of the above networks is the sensitivity to the loss of the guest molecules, which could be partly due to the inherently flexible nature of the thioether−Ag(I) interaction (alas, flexibility is a two-edged sword). For improving the network stability, one could exchange the original guests (e.g., nitrobenzene and benzene) with less volatile molecules (e.g., biphenyls or anthracene). Or one could follow a previously established two-step protocol: first build up a coordination net from molecules with cross-linkable groups (such as -OH), and then introduce a cross-linking agent to strengthen the network with covalent bonds. The improved stability would then create more opportunity to utilize the large aromatic π-systems for solid-state sensing applications and for studying charge transfer phenomena within the crystalline porous system.

For improving the network stability, one could exchange the original guests (e.g., nitrobenzene and benzene) with less volatile molecules (e.g., biphenyls or anthracene). Or one could follow a previously established two-step protocol: first build up a coordination net from molecules with cross-linkable groups (such as -OH), and then introduce a cross-linking agent to strengthen the network with covalent bonds. The improved stability would then create more opportunity to utilize the large aromatic π-systems for solid-state sensing applications and for studying charge transfer phenomena within the crystalline porous system.

elements.content: We have sought to highlight the flexible nature of the interaction between thioethers and Ag(I) ions that is exhibited in their exceptionally variable bonding distances. The flexible nature of the thioether−Ag(I) bonding apparently helps to crystallize the coordination networks reported here, and enables us to probe the network formation behaviors of a group of large-size, branchy organic molecular building blocks with complex multidentate characteristics. The key features of the resultant networks are illustrated in the manifold local coordination motif of compound 1, the coexistence of bonding and free-standing thioether groups in 2, and the supramolecular topology in 3. Further exercise with more elaborate molecular structures should continue to uncover intriguing structures for better understanding of complex coordination networks. The most complex crystals, no doubt, are those of proteins and other biomacromolecules. In this regard, the field of coordination networks certainly has a long course to travel for achieving higher structural and functional sophistications, and thioethers might help provide an express lane for us to move forward.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have sought to highlight the flexible nature of the interaction between thioethers and Ag(I) ions that is exhibited in their exceptionally variable bonding distances. The flexible nature of the thioether-Ag(I) bonding apparently helps to crystallize the coordination networks reported here, and enables us to probe the network formation behaviors of a group of large-size, branchy organic molecular building blocks with complex multidentate characteristics. The key features of the resultant networks are illustrated in the manifold local coordination motif of compound 1, the coexistence of bonding and free-standing thioether groups in 2, and the supramolecular topology in 3. Further exercise with more elaborate molecular structures should continue to uncover intriguing structures for better understanding of complex coordination networks. The most complex crystals, no doubt, are those of proteins and other biomacromolecules. In this regard, the field of coordination networks certainly has a long course to travel for achieving higher structural and functional sophistications, and thioethers might help provide an express lane for us to move forward.

cln_elements.content:
A Schlenk tube (100 mL) was loaded with a magnetic stirring bar, bis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(II) chloride (70.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), triphenylphosphine (120.0 mg, 0.46 mmol), copper(I) iodide (35.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), 4-ethynyl-3,4,5-tris(methylthio)benzene (0.50 g, 2.08 mmol), and tris(4-iodophenyl)amine (0.39 g, 0.63 mmol). The Schlenk tube was then connected to a vacuum manifold, evacuated, and back-filled with nitrogen gas. After the Schlenk was thus purged three times, a 2:1 triethylamine/tetrahydrofuran (THF) mixture (30.0 mL, prepurged with nitrogen gas) was injected via cannula under nitrogen protection. The Schlenk tube was then sealed with the plug and stirred at 100 °C overnight. After being cooled down to rt, the reaction mixture was worked up by the same procedure as that used for 1-trimethylsilylethynyl-3,4,5-tris(methylthio)benzene (see ). The crude product was then purified by flash chromatography (silica gel, flash column separation with 1:1 hexane/dichloromethane as the eluent) to provide a light yellow solid (0.30 g, 50% based on tris(4-iodophenyl)amine). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 2.36 (s, 9H), 2.46 (s, 18H), 6.97 (s, 6H), 7.10 (d, 6H), 7.47 (d, 6H) ppm. 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 18.90, 20.86, 89.23, 91.10, 117.90, 122.16, 124.50, 125.31, 128.47, 133.49, 147.30, 147.45 ppm.

X-ray Quality Single Crystals of L1·2AgBF<sub>4</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A nitrobenzene (NB) solution (2.0 mL) of L1 (9.6 mg, 0.01 mmol) was added to an NB solution (2.0 mL) of AgBF4 (3.9 mg, 0.02 mmol) in a vial and the mixture was filtered to give a light yellow solution. The filtrate (held in a loosely capped vial) was then placed into a larger vial containing about 10 mL of hexane, with care taken to prevent direct contact of the filtrate and the hexane. The larger vial was then sealed tight and placed in a dark, quiet place for the vapor transport experiment. White needle-like single crystals (10.0 mg, 74% yield based on L1) suitable for X-ray data set collection were formed over a period of about 7 days. To help determine the chemical composition of the as-synthesized crystals, freshly made crystals of 1 (3.0 mg) were dissolved in a mixture of DMSO-d 6 (0.5 mL) and CDCl3 (0.5 mL) for 1H NMR measurement. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6, CDCl3): δ 7.03 (s, 12H), 7.10 (d, 12H), 7.56 (d, 12H), 7.68 (t, 6H), 7.85 (t, 3H) and 8.23 (d, 6H) ppm. The NMR spectra of 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6 , CDCl3) for nitrobenzene: δ 7.58 (t, 2H), 7.74 (t, 1H), 8.20 (d, 2H) ppm. Combined with the above NMR data of pure L1, the L1/NB ratio is thus established as 1:1.25 (i.e., L1·2AgBF4·1.25C6H5NO2). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for L1·2AgBF4·1.25C6H5NO2: C 46.7, H 3.44, N 2.10; found: C 45.16, H 3.61, N 2.04. This composition is also supported by the TGA measurement (see ).

2H-5,10,15,20-Tetrakis[3′,4′,5′-tris(phenylthio)phenyl]porphyrin (2H-T3PhTPP)

To an oxygen-free solution of 3,4,5-tris(phenylthio)benzaldehyde (0.43 g, 1.0 mmol) in dichloromethane (anhydrous, 50.0 mL) was added pyrrole (68.0 mg, 99.0%, 1.0 mmol, prepurged with nitrogen for 5 min) under nitrogen protection. After 5 min, boron trifluoride diethyl etherate (0.1 mL, 1 M in dichloromethane) was injected, while the mixture was stirred using a magnetic stirring bar. The mixture was then covered with the aluminum foil and the stirring was continued for another 2 h, followed by addition of p-chloranil (2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzoquinone, 0.20 g, 99.0%, 0.82 mmol) into the resultant dark red-brown solution. The burgundy mixture was then heated to reflux for 1 h. After the mixture was cooled to rt, the mixture was transferred into a round-bottom flask and silica gel was added. The solvent was removed in vacuo, and the purple residue was loaded on the top of a prepacked silica gel column. The column was eluted first with 50% (by volume) dichloromethane in hexane to remove the side products, and then with 70% dichloromethane in hexane to get the sample. After evaporation of the solvent in vacuo, the pure product was obtained as a shiny purple solid (0.29 g, mp 335−337 °C w/ decomposition, 60% yield based on 3,4,5-tris(phenylthio)benzaldehyde). 1H NMR (200 MHz, DMF-d 6): δ 7.06−7.30 (m, 24H), 7.36 (s, 8H), 7.56−7.73 (m, 36H), 8.85 (s, 8H) ppm. Solution 13C NMR could not be obtained from our instruments due to the low solubility in common deuterated solvents. Further characterization could be found in the single crystal X-ray diffraction study of the extended networks based on Zn-T3PhTPP and silver triflate.

Zinc(II)-5,10,15,20-tetrakis[3′,4′,5′-tris(phenylthio)phenyl]porphyrin (<bold>L2</bold>: Zn-T3PhTPP)

This was obtained in 99.0% yield as a red purple solid by refluxing a mixture of 2H-T3PhTPP (0.12 g, 0.063 mmol) and zinc acetate dihydrate (0.14 g, 99%, 0.63 mmol) in chloroform (dry, 30.0 mL) for 1 h followed by filtration through a silica gel plug. Solution NMR could not be obtained from our instruments due to the low solubility in common deuterated solvents. Further characterization was provided by the crystallographic study of the hybrid extended network based on this compound.

X-ray Quality Single Crystals of L2·2AgOTf (<bold>2</bold>)

A nitrobenzene solution of Zn-T3PhTPP (0.50 mL, 1.4 mM) and a nitrobenzene solution of silver triflate (AgOTf, 0.5 mL, 11.2 mM) were mixed in a vial. After adding N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) (0.1 mL) to dissolve the precipitate, the solution was filtered through a syringe frit into another vial. The vial with the filtrate was then placed into a bigger vial containing a reservoir of benzene (∼10 mL). The bigger vial was tightly capped and placed in the dark for the vapor transport experiment. After 10 days, purple-red, block-like crystals (1.7 mg, 41% yield based on L2) suitable for X-ray data set collection were obtained. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for L2·2AgOTf·DMA·2C6H6·C6H5NO2: C 58.87, H 3.60, N 2.94; found: C 57.91, H 3.52, N 2.84. This composition is also supported by the TGA measurement (see   ).

2,3,6,7,10,11-Hexakis(4-methylthiophenyl)triphenylene (<bold>L3</bold>)

To a Schlenk tube containing a mixture of 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexabromotriphenylene (0.702 g, 1.0 mmol) and tetrakis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(0) (0.30 g, 0.26 mmol) in toluene (25.0 mL) were added a suspension of 4-methylthiophenylboronic acid (1.68 g, 10.0 mmol) in ethanol (8.0 mL) and an aqueous solution of potassium carbonate (5.0 mL, 2.0 M) under nitrogen protection. The mixture was heated under reflux at 120 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature and poured into dichloromethane. The organic layer was washed with water, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified on silica gel using a mixture of dichloromethane and hexane (the CH2Cl2/hexane ratio was varied gradually from 1:2 to 1:1) to yield a white solid (0.52 g, 54% yield based on 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexabromotriphenylene). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 2.51 (s, 18H), 7.22 (m, 24H), 8.63 (s, 6H) ppm. 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 15.89, 125.76, 126.35, 129.13, 130.65, 137.49, 138.26, 139.53 ppm.

X-ray Quality Single Crystals of 2L3·5AgOTf (<bold>3</bold>)

A nitrobenzene (NB) solution (2.0 mL) of L3 (19.2 mg, 0.02 mmol) was added to an NB solution (4.0 mL) of AgOTf (25.7 mg, 0.1 mmol) in a vial and the mixture was filtered to give a light yellow solution. The filtrate (held in a loosely capped vial) was then placed into a larger vial containing about 20 mL of hexane, with care taken to prevent direct contact of the filtrate and the hexane. The larger vial was then sealed tight and placed in a dark, quiet place for the vapor transport experiment. White needle-like single crystals (21.0 mg, 58.5% yield based on L3) suitable for X-ray data set collection were formed over a period of about 7 days. X-ray powder diffraction of the product indicated a single phase consistent with the single crystal structure (see   ). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 2L3·5AgOTf·2H2O·1.5C6H5NO2: C 48.74, H 3.24, N 0.64; found: C 48.33, H 3.33, N 0.62. This composition is also supported by TGA measurements (see   ).

Tris{[3,4,5-Tris(methylthio)phenyl]ethynyl}phenylamine (L1)

A Schlenk tube (100 mL) was loaded with a magnetic stirring bar, bis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(II) chloride (70.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), triphenylphosphine (120.0 mg, 0.46 mmol), copper(I) iodide (35.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), 4-ethynyl-3,4,5-tris(methylthio)benzene (0.50 g, 2.08 mmol), and tris(4-iodophenyl)amine (0.39 g, 0.63 mmol). The Schlenk tube was then connected to a vacuum manifold, evacuated, and back-filled with nitrogen gas. After the Schlenk was thus purged three times, a 2:1 triethylamine/tetrahydrofuran (THF) mixture (30.0 mL, prepurged with nitrogen gas) was injected via cannula under nitrogen protection. The Schlenk tube was then sealed with the plug and stirred at 100 °C overnight. After being cooled down to rt, the reaction mixture was worked up by the same procedure as that used for 1-trimethylsilylethynyl-3,4,5-tris(methylthio)benzene (see ). The crude product was then purified by flash chromatography (silica gel, flash column separation with 1:1 hexane/dichloromethane as the eluent) to provide a light yellow solid (0.30 g, 50% based on tris(4-iodophenyl)amine). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 2.36 (s, 9H), 2.46 (s, 18H), 6.97 (s, 6H), 7.10 (d, 6H), 7.47 (d, 6H) ppm. 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 18.90, 20.86, 89.23, 91.10, 117.90, 122.16, 124.50, 125.31, 128.47, 133.49, 147.30, 147.45 ppm.

X-ray Quality Single Crystals of L1⋅2AgBF4 (1)

A nitrobenzene (NB) solution (2.0 mL) of L1 (9.6 mg, 0.01 mmol) was added to an NB solution (2.0 mL) of AgBF4 (3.9 mg, 0.02 mmol) in a vial and the mixture was filtered to give a light yellow solution. The filtrate (held in a loosely capped vial) was then placed into a larger vial containing about 10 mL of hexane, with care taken to prevent direct contact of the filtrate and the hexane. The larger vial was then sealed tight and placed in a dark, quiet place for the vapor transport experiment. White needle-like single crystals (10.0 mg, 74% yield based on L1) suitable for X-ray data set collection were formed over a period of about 7 days. To help determine the chemical composition of the as-synthesized crystals, freshly made crystals of 1 (3.0 mg) were dissolved in a mixture of DMSO-d 6 (0.5 mL) and CDCl3 (0.5 mL) for 1H NMR measurement. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6, CDCl3): δ 7.03 (s, 12H), 7.10 (d, 12H), 7.56 (d, 12H), 7.68 (t, 6H), 7.85 (t, 3H) and 8.23 (d, 6H) ppm. The NMR spectra of 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d  6 , CDCl3) for nitrobenzene: δ 7.58 (t, 2H), 7.74 (t, 1H), 8.20 (d, 2H) ppm. Combined with the above NMR data of pure L1, the L1/NB ratio is thus established as 1:1.25 (i.e., L1⋅2AgBF4⋅1.25C6H5NO2). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for L1⋅2AgBF4⋅1.25C6H5NO2: C 46.7, H 3.44, N 2.10; found: C 45.16, H 3.61, N 2.04. This composition is also supported by the TGA measurement (see ).

2H-5,10,15,20-Tetrakis[3',4',5'-tris(phenylthio)phenyl]porphyrin (2H-T3PhTPP)

To an oxygen-free solution of 3,4,5-tris(phenylthio)benzaldehyde (0.43 g, 1.0 mmol) in dichloromethane (anhydrous, 50.0 mL) was added pyrrole (68.0 mg, 99.0%, 1.0 mmol, prepurged with nitrogen for 5 min) under nitrogen protection. After 5 min, boron trifluoride diethyl etherate (0.1 mL, 1 M in dichloromethane) was injected, while the mixture was stirred using a magnetic stirring bar. The mixture was then covered with the aluminum foil and the stirring was continued for another 2 h, followed by addition of p-chloranil (2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzoquinone, 0.20 g, 99.0%, 0.82 mmol) into the resultant dark red-brown solution. The burgundy mixture was then heated to reflux for 1 h. After the mixture was cooled to rt, the mixture was transferred into a round-bottom flask and silica gel was added. The solvent was removed in vacuo, and the purple residue was loaded on the top of a prepacked silica gel column. The column was eluted first with 50% (by volume) dichloromethane in hexane to remove the side products, and then with 70% dichloromethane in hexane to get the sample. After evaporation of the solvent in vacuo, the pure product was obtained as a shiny purple solid (0.29 g, mp 335-337 °C w/ decomposition, 60% yield based on 3,4,5-tris(phenylthio)benzaldehyde). 1H NMR (200 MHz, DMF-d 6): δ 7.06-7.30 (m, 24H), 7.36 (s, 8H), 7.56-7.73 (m, 36H), 8.85 (s, 8H) ppm. Solution 13C NMR could not be obtained from our instruments due to the low solubility in common deuterated solvents. Further characterization could be found in the single crystal X-ray diffraction study of the extended networks based on Zn-T3PhTPP and silver triflate.

Zinc(II)-5,10,15,20-tetrakis[3',4',5'-tris(phenylthio)phenyl]porphyrin (L2: Zn-T3PhTPP)

This was obtained in 99.0% yield as a red purple solid by refluxing a mixture of 2H-T3PhTPP (0.12 g, 0.063 mmol) and zinc acetate dihydrate (0.14 g, 99%, 0.63 mmol) in chloroform (dry, 30.0 mL) for 1 h followed by filtration through a silica gel plug. Solution NMR could not be obtained from our instruments due to the low solubility in common deuterated solvents. Further characterization was provided by the crystallographic study of the hybrid extended network based on this compound.

Distribution of pyridyl N···Ag+, N···Cu+, nitrile N···Ag+, N···Cu+, and thioether S···Ag+, S···Cu+ distances in CSD database. A distance of 2.6 Å on R2S···Ag+ registers a rank of 0.4, meaning 2.6 Å is longer than 40% of all the thioether S···Ag+ contacts retrieved. The steep step of the C5H5N···Cu+ curve thus indicates a large majority of the contacts occur around 2.0 Å, while the slower slope of R2S···Ag+ indicates a wider distribution of the distances (the sampling size is big, with over 800 data points retrieved for each type of contact).
